thread.title: Brexit: Labour chair Ian Lavery says there is 'no prospect of a decent Brexit deal being passed through Parliament'

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit: Labour chair Ian Lavery says there is 'no prospect of a decent Brexit deal being passed through Parliament'
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Hopes that Theresa May’s Cabinet is close to signing off a Brexit deal appear to have been dashed, as both the EU and UK sides said issues remain to be settled.
The EU’s chief negotiator said on Mondau that the main elements of an agreement are ready to present to the UK Cabinet, suggesting ortuous negotiations to agree a Brexit deal appear to be reaching an end.
Michel Barnier told EU ministers that “the parameters of a possible agreement are very largely defined” and would now go to the Cabinet for discussion.
But Downing Street said the comment should be taken “with a bucket of salt”.
It is not thought that any deal will be on the table at the Cabinet meeting in 10 Downing Street, which will instead hear an update on negotiations and discuss preparations for a possible no-deal withdrawal from the EU.
It’s also unclear whether Prime Minister Theresa May will be able to win the support of Parliament for her plans.
Rising exports show why the North East NEEDS a Brexit deal to let trade continue
Labour chair Ian Lavery said there was “’no prospect of a decent Brexit deal being passed through Parliament” but Labour was ready to form a Government and “pick up this mess”.
Former Home Secretary Boris Johnson has urged the Cabinet to “mutiny” against the Prime Minister, saying she was “on the verge of total surrender” to Brussels.
And this came after his brother Jo Johnson, who unlike Boris backed the ‘remain’ campaign in the 2016 referendum, resigned as a Transport Minister and called for a second referendum on Brexit.
While the Conservative Party is deeply divided over Brexit, there were also suggestions of disagreements within the Labour Party.
Asked last week if he would stop Brexit if he could, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said: “We can’t stop it.” Labour shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer (Image: Daily Record)
Critics said this flew in the face of the policy agreed at Labour’s annual conference in September, when the party agreed that to keep the option of a second referendum “on the table” if Mrs May fails to agree a satisfactory Brexit deal, and if there is no general election.
Sir Keir Starmer, Labour’s Shadow Brexit Secretary, said: “Brexit can be stopped – but the real question is what are the decisions we are going to face over the next few weeks and months.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
Mr Lavery, MP for Wansbeck, said Labour’s policy was to “leave all options on the table”.
He told ChronicleLive: “Theresa May has had two years to seek a Brexit deal with the EU. Instead she’s created political mayhem with unprecedented uncertainty here in the UK.
“Her Cabinet, her front bench and indeed her backbenchers cannot agree on her Brexit proposals. The undertaker has been called for the chequers deal yet Theresa May still prefers it. Read More
